stem: Subcooled water enters the bottom of an operating reactor core. As the water flows upward past the fuel assemblies, steam bubbles form on the surface of a few fuel rods and are swept away. If the coolant at the surface of the affected fuel rods had remained subcooled, average fuel temperature in the affected fuel rods would have been __________ because single-phase convection is a __________ efficient method of heat transfer than boiling. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: lower; less -900- PWR Test Items

stem: The heat transfer coefficient for the core will be directly increased if: (Assume bulk coolant subcooling.)

choices.B: the coolant flow rate is decreased.
choices.C: nucleate boiling occurs in the coolant.
choices.D: the coolant flow is laminar instead of turbulent.

stem: Increasing the coolant flow rate through a reactor core affects the heat transfer rate from the fuel, because a higher coolant flow rate results in a __________ laminar film thickness and a __________ coolant temperature adjacent to the fuel. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: smaller; lower -901- PWR Test Items

stem: Which one of the following will minimize core heat transfer? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: Laminar flow with no nucleate boiling.
choices.B: Turbulent flow with no nucleate boiling.
choices.D: Turbulent flow with nucleate boiling. -902- PWR Test Items

stem: Refer to the drawing of a fuel rod and adjacent coolant flow channel (see figure below). With a nuclear power plant operating at steady-state 100 percent reactor power at the beginning of a fuel cycle, which one of the following has the greater temperature difference? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: Coolant laminar layer -903- PWR Test Items

stem: Refer to the drawing of a section of pipe that contains flowing subcooled water (see figure below). Given:  Pressure at P is 24 psig. 1  Pressure at P is 16 psig. 2  Pressure change due to change in velocity is 2 psig.  Pressure change due to change in elevation is 10 psig. The pressure decrease due to friction head loss between P and P is __________; and the direction 1 2 of flow is from __________. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 4 psig; right to left -904- PWR Test Items

stem: Refer to the drawing of a section of pipe that contains flowing subcooled water (see figure below). Given:  Pressure at P is 26 psig. 1  Pressure at P is 34 psig. 2  Pressure change due to change in velocity is 2 psig.  Pressure change due to change in elevation is 8 psig. The pressure decrease due to friction head loss between P and P is __________; and the direction 1 2 of flow is from __________. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 4 psig; right to left -905- PWR Test Items

stem: Refer to the drawing of a section of pipe that contains flowing subcooled water. (See figure below). Given:  Pressure at P is 30 psig. 1  Pressure at P is 32 psig. 2  Pressure change due to change in velocity is 2 psig.  Pressure change due to change in elevation is 2 psig. The pressure decrease due to friction head loss between P and P is __________; and the direction 1 2 of flow is from __________. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 6 psig; right to left -906- PWR Test Items

stem: Refer to the drawing of a section of pipe that contains flowing subcooled water (see figure below). Given:  Pressure at P is 34 psig. 1  Pressure at P is 20 psig. 2  Pressure change due to change in velocity is 2 psig.  Pressure change due to change in elevation is 8 psig. The pressure decrease due to friction head loss between P and P is __________; and the direction 1 2 of flow is from __________. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 4 psig; right to left -907- PWR Test Items

stem: Refer to the drawing of a section of pipe that contains flowing subcooled water (see figure below). Given:  The pressure at P is 20 psig. 1  The pressure at P is 20 psig. 2  The pressure change caused by the change in velocity is 2 psig.  The pressure change caused by the change in elevation is 8 psig. The pressure decrease due to friction head loss between P and P is __________; and the direction 1 2 of flow is from __________. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 10 psig; right to left -908- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is producing 3,400 MW of thermal output with a reactor vessel differential temperature (ΔT) of 60°F and a reactor vessel mass flow rate of 1.4 x 108 lbm/hr. If core ΔT is 63.6°F, what is core bypass mass flow rate? (Assume bypass flow ΔT equals 0°F.)

choices.D: 1.32 x 108 lbm/hr

stem: A reactor is producing 3,400 MW of thermal output with a reactor vessel differential temperature (ΔT) of 60°F and a reactor vessel mass flow rate of 1.0 x 108 lbm/hr. If core ΔT is 63.6°F, what is core bypass mass flow rate? (Assume bypass flow ΔT equals 0°F.) NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 9.43 x 107 lbm/hr -909- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is producing 3,400 MW of thermal output with a reactor vessel differential temperature (ΔT) of 60°F and a reactor vessel mass flow rate of 1.1 x 108 lbm/hr. If core ΔT is 63.6°F, what is core bypass mass flow rate? (Assume bypass flow ΔT equals 0°F.)

choices.D: 6.23 x 107 lbm/hr

stem: Adequate core bypass flow is needed to... NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: cool the excore nuclear instrument detectors.
choices.B: provide cooling to core structural components.
choices.C: provide primary sodium pump minimum flow requirements.
choices.D: prevent stratification of coolant below the cover gas. -910- PWR Test Items

stem: Which one of the following describes a function of core bypass flow?

choices.A: Provides a means of measuring core flow rate.
choices.B: Provide primary sodium pump minimum flow requirements.
choices.C: Prevents excessive reactor vessel wall differential temperature.
choices.D: Provides cooling to various reactor vessel internal components.

stem: Which one of the following is a function of core bypass flow? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: Provides cooling to core structural components.
choices.B: Provides even coolant flow distribution through the fuel.
choices.C: Ensures natural circulation will be initiated when forced circulation is lost.
choices.D: Ensures core exit thermocouple readings represent average fuel temperatures. -911- PWR Test Items

stem: Which one of the following must exist for natural circulation flow to occur?

choices.A: The heat source must be larger than the heat sink.
choices.B: The heat source must be located higher than the heat sink.
choices.C: The heat sink must be larger than the heat source.
choices.D: The heat sink must be located higher than the heat source.

stem: The driving head for natural circulation flow through the core is developed by differences in __________ between the heat sink and the heat source. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: pipe length -912- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is shut down with natural circulation core cooling. Decay heat generation is equivalent to 1.0 percent of rated thermal power. Stable natural circulation mass flow rate is 1,000 gpm. When decay heat generation decreases to 0.5 percent of rated thermal power, stable natural circulation flow rate will be approximately...

choices.D: 794 gpm.

stem: A reactor is shut down with natural circulation core cooling. Decay heat generation is equivalent to 1.0 percent of rated thermal power. Core differential temperature (ΔT) has stabilized at 16°F. When decay heat generation decreases to 0.5 percent of rated thermal power, core ΔT will be approximately... NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 10°F. -913- PWR Test Items

stem: Sustained natural circulation requires that the heat sink is __________ in elevation than the heat source and that there is a __________ difference between the heat sink and the heat source.

choices.D: higher; temperature

stem: Which one of the following conditions must occur to sustain natural convection in a fluid system? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.B: A phase change in the fluid.
choices.C: A density change in the fluid.
choices.D: Radiative heat transfer to the fluid. -914- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is shut down with natural circulation core cooling. Decay heat generation is equivalent to 1.0 percent of rated thermal power. Core differential temperature (ΔT) has stabilized at 16°F. When decay heat generation decreases to 0.333 percent of rated thermal power, core ΔT will be approximately...

A reactor is shut down with natural circulation core cooling. Decay heat generation is equivalent to 1.0 percent of rated thermal power. Core differential temperature (ΔT) has stabilized at 13°F. When decay heat generation decreases to 0.5 percent of rated thermal power, core ΔT will be approximately... NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 10°F. -915- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is shut down with natural circulation core cooling. Decay heat generation is equivalent to 1.0 percent of rated thermal power. Stable natural circulation flow rate is 800 gpm. When decay heat generation decreases to 0.5 percent of rated thermal power, stable natural circulation flow rate will be approximately...

choices.D: 696 gpm.

stem: Sustained natural circulation requires that the heat source is __________ in elevation than the heat sink; and that there is a __________ difference between the heat source and the heat sink. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: higher; temperature -916- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor had been operating at 100 percent power for 3 months when a loss of offsite power occurred, causing a reactor trip and a loss of forced reactor coolant flow. If forced reactor coolant flow is not restored, which one of the following describes the relationship between reactor coolant hot leg and cold leg temperatures one hour after the reactor trip?

choices.A: Hot leg temperature will be greater than cold leg temperature because natural circulation cooling flow occurs in the same direction as forced reactor coolant flow.
choices.B: Hot leg temperature will be less than cold leg temperature because natural circulation cooling flow occurs in the opposite direction as forced reactor coolant flow.
choices.C: Hot leg temperature will be approximately the same as cold leg temperature because only the density of the reactor coolant changes during natural circulation cooling.
choices.D: Hot leg temperature will be approximately the same as cold leg temperature because the reactor does not produce a significant amount of heat one hour after a reactor trip.

stem: Natural circulation flow can be enhanced by... NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: increasing the elevation of the heat source to equal that of the heat sink.
choices.B: increasing the temperature difference between the heat source and the heat sink.
choices.C: decreasing the temperature difference between the heat source and the heat sink.
choices.D: decreasing the elevation difference between the heat source and the heat sink. -917- PWR Test Items
